s.text: Bradley won the high ground on campaign reform by offering a comprehensive reform plan while teaming up with John McCain against a fund-raising system whose corruption McCain helpfully traced to the Clinton-Gore White House.
If Gore succeeds in linking the two issues this way, Bradley will lose the health-care debate, and with it the nomination.
If Gore succeeds in linking the two issues this way, Bradley will lose the health-care debate, and with it the nomination.

"Experience shows there's a set amount of money that communities have been willing to spend on education," Gore argued on Meet the Press . "If you drain the money away from the public schools for private vouchers, then that hurts the public schools."

"Experience shows there's a set amount of money that communities have been willing to spend on education," Gore argued on Meet the Press . "If you drain the money away from the public schools for private vouchers, then that hurts the public schools."
Gore won the high ground on education by proposing a $115 billion school aid package while portraying Bradley as a voucher sympathizer.
In the second stage, the candidates fought for the high ground on those three issues.
On firearms and campaign finance, he defined reform as government control.
